text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with whole-grain blueberry scones
that's right I had some gorgeous
blueberries which I wanted to use in
something very delicious but I couldn't
decide whether I wanted to use these in
a muffin a scone or a doughnut so I
ended up doing something that's kind of
a combination of all three in fact I
almost portmanteau this into something
called a Moscow nut but then I was told
by my search engine consultants that
Moscow nut is not a super popular
internet search so we're just going to
call it a whole-grain blueberry scone
and this is how you put it together
alright so for the dough we're going to
need some whole grain flour and I'm
usually something called sprouted spelt
flour which you may remember from such
videos is spelt a pizza dough and as
usual I'll give more info about this on
the blog but this stuff is just a
wonderful all purpose flour and not only
is it high in protein but it's also very
light and mild tasting for a whole grain
and then to that we're going to add some
baking powder as well as baking soda
we're also going to need a little bit of
salt of course and then because I did
want these to have a little bit of
old-fashioned donut to them we're going
to do a little pinch of nutmeg freshly
grated of course as well as a little
pinch of cinnamon and then just because
it goes so well with blueberries I
decided to grate in a little lemon zest
and that's basically it for the dry
ingredients and as usual we'll take a
whisk and we'll mix that thoroughly
mostly to make sure everything's nicely
combined and we don't have any chunks of
baking powder or baking soda hiding
anywhere and then once that's mixed we
have a little decision to make whether
or not you want to add a little sugar so
my feeling is if you're making these for
like a weekday breakfast treat then I
probably wouldn't add any but if you're
going for something that's a little
closer to a special occasion pastry then
I would go ahead and add a couple
tablespoons which is what I'm doing here
since I'm going to pass this off as a
Mother's Day brunch idea and once that
set we can move on to the incredibly
important step of cutting in the butter
except we're not going to cut it in as
usual we're going to grade it in so what
you want to do before you start this is
put a stick of butter in the freezer and
then we're going to use a cheese grater
to grate that butter into the flour
mixture and basically that's going to
give us the same little pieces of butter
that we would get using a pastry blender
or pastry cutter for this so this
technique does work very well but one
tip every couple tablespoons or so take
your fork and kind of toss those grated
pieces of butter into the flour so they
don't clump together
and we'll just continue doing that until
all the butters graded in so as long as
you don't slip and gray a fingernail off
oh man that's the worst this really is a
fantastic technique so our butters been
cut in quote-unquote and we can proceed
but because my fork doesn't have any
nerve endings in it I wanted to give
this a double check with my fingers and
if the mixture seems a little coarse in
other words the butter pieces might be
too big you can just rub it between your
fingers like this to break it down a
little more but mine felt pretty good so
at that point I was ready to grab my
blueberries and add those in and we'll
give those a quick toss before adding
our liquid which in this case is
buttermilk and then all we want to do is
take our fork and give this a mix until
it just comes together okay usually at
this point we form a dough ball and then
roll it out and cut our scones but I
much prefer to do my dough forming right
down the work surface so as soon as it
comes together like this I'm going to
transfer that onto my table it will kind
of smoosh and push and press this all
together and all we're trying to do here
is to get this into some kind of rough
rectangular shape and fair warning
because we did not mix this all the way
in the bowl you're gonna have some spots
that are wet and sticky and other spots
are going to be dry and crumbly but
that's totally normal
just relax just keep pushing patting and
pressing until you have something looks
like this at which point we're going to
take our bench scraper and we're
basically going to give this a try fold
so we'll get under with our scraper and
fold that third over and then we'll fold
the other third over the top and then
we'll turn it and again press it back
into a rectangular shape and any of
those rogue crumbs you see you can just
press into the dough no problem and I
don't think we want to press this too
thin so mine was probably an inch and a
quarter inch and a half thick so like I
said we're gonna form that back into a
rectangle at which point we're ready to
cut our scones
so first I'm going to cut this in half
and then in half the other way to make
four rectangles and then each of the
four rectangles we will cut in half
diagonally to make triangles which if
you take your time and do this evenly
like I definitely did not you should get
some beautiful right angle triangles
mine were a little more isosceles than I
would have liked but hey this is home AK
not geometry am i right besides who the
heck wants to eat a perfect scone that's
not a good look and then once those are
cut we're going to transfer those onto
some kind of lined baking sheet I like
to use the Silpat but I'm sure part
and paper would work and if we wanted we
could pop these in the oven right now
and they would look pretty good but we
generally don't like to settle for
pretty good we want these to look
stunning
so to help us achieve that we're going
to paint the tops with a little extra
buttermilk all right a nice generous
application on top of each one and once
that's been brushed on we will finish
with a little bit of granulated sugar
and what I like to use is something
called Demerara sugar which has a nice
big crystal and not only is that going
to look incredible it's going to give it
a beautiful crunch and yes of course you
can just use regular sugar if you want I
mean you're the Andrew Bogut of what we
almost called a muffs Co nut so that's
up to you
both will work beautifully and then once
those have been sugared we can go ahead
and transfer those into the center of a
preheated 425 degree oven for about 25
minutes or until they look like this
they should basically look like one of
the most beautiful baked things you've
ever seen and of course is Murphy's Law
would have it there must have been a
large cluster of fruit in the tip of
that smallest cone which cause what we
call in the business a blueberry blowout
but that was no big deal
I just fixed it by biting that piece off
and then of course the bad news as usual
let these cool down before you eat them
okay fine
you can try one when they're a little
warm but you really do want to let those
cool down on the pan at least 15 or 20
minutes at which point we can transfer
onto a plate and dig in and as gorgeous
as I think these look the taste and
texture was just as good all right they
had this beautiful flaky crispy crusty
exterior and then the inside had a very
light very tender texture it was just
moist enough and as I mentioned earlier
that little bit of spice we added gives
these blueberry scones just a little
hint of old-fashioned donut which I
think elevated these into something a
little extra special and of course if
there happened to be an occasion or
holiday coming up we're serving someone
breakfast in bed would be appropriate
you know like Mother's Day for example
these would be perfect but anyway that's
it whole grain blueberry scones so
whether you're going to make these to
finally impress someone in bed or you're
just going to whip up a batch for a
delicious weekday breakfast treat I
really hope you give these a try soon
so head over to food wishes calm for all
the ingredient amounts and MorphOS usual
and as always enjoy
